domains.name: Quality Assurance
domains.description: Artifacts and rules that define how functional, non-functional, and AI-specific quality is validated, including test strategies, execution evidence, defect handling, coverage, and release readiness.

terms.name: Test Strategy
terms.definition: A high-level document defining testing scope, testing types, testing levels, test coverage goals, and overall quality approach for the Product.
terms.description: Defines the overall quality approach and the testing categories required to establish confidence before release.

terms.name: Test Plan
terms.definition: A document describing how testing will be executed, including activities, timelines, environments, resources, and responsibilities.
terms.description: Defines the operational plan for testing execution, including who does what, where tests run, and how results are recorded.

terms.name: Testing Scope
terms.definition: A definition of the boundaries of testing, specifying what will be tested and what will not be tested.
terms.description: Constrains test effort to agreed coverage boundaries and prevents ambiguous expectations about what is validated.

terms.name: Testing Levels
terms.definition: The structured layers of testing applied to the system, such as unit, integration, system, and acceptance testing.
terms.description: Defines where tests run in the architecture and what each level is responsible for validating.

terms.name: Test Environment
terms.definition: A controlled technical environment configured specifically for executing tests, including infrastructure, data, configurations, integrations, and versioning.
terms.description: Defines the runtime context in which tests execute to ensure repeatability and valid results.

terms.name: Roles and Responsibilities (Test Context)
terms.definition: A section in the Test Plan defining which roles are responsible for planning, executing, validating, and reporting testing activities.
terms.description: Defines accountability for test design, execution, verification, and reporting to prevent coverage gaps.

terms.name: Test Case
terms.definition: A structured description of a specific test scenario including inputs, actions, expected results, and validation steps.
terms.description: Defines a repeatable test procedure with expected outcomes to validate behavior systematically.

terms.name: Test Data Set
terms.definition: A predefined collection of data values used to execute Test Cases consistently and reliably.
terms.description: Defines the data used to run tests so outcomes are comparable across runs and environments.

terms.name: Data Conditioning
terms.definition: The process of preparing, adjusting, or transforming test data to ensure it supports specific testing scenarios.
terms.description: Defines how test data is created and modified to meet scenario preconditions and boundary cases.

terms.name: Test Cycle
terms.definition: A coordinated execution of a group of Test Cases intended to validate a defined portion of system behavior.
terms.description: Defines an execution batch used to validate a scope slice and to produce consolidated results.

terms.name: Execution Results
terms.definition: A structured record of outcomes of executed test cases, including pass/fail status, observations, and evidence.
terms.description: Records what happened during execution, including evidence needed for release readiness decisions.

terms.name: Test Coverage Matrix
terms.definition: A structured mapping showing relationships between requirements, user stories, workflows, and test cases to ensure coverage.
terms.description: Defines coverage traceability to ensure every required behavior has validation and to identify gaps.

terms.name: Interaction Coverage
terms.definition: A validation ensuring that interaction-level behaviors defined in interaction specifications, user flows, and screen structures are fully tested.
terms.description: Ensures UI and interaction behaviors are not omitted from testing and are validated against defined interaction rules.

terms.name: Defect Report
terms.definition: A structured record of an identified defect including description, reproduction steps, expected behavior, actual behavior, severity, and impact.
terms.description: Captures actionable defect information required for triage, fixing, and verification.

terms.name: Defect Severity and Priority Rules
terms.definition: A standardized classification system used to categorize defects by impact (severity) and urgency (priority).
terms.description: Defines consistent triage rules so defects are handled objectively and aligned with release risk.

terms.name: Defect Lifecycle
terms.definition: A defined sequence of stages a defect passes through, such as New, Assigned, In Progress, Fixed, Verified, and Closed.
terms.description: Defines the workflow for defect handling to ensure visibility, accountability, and closure control.

terms.name: Test Summary Report
terms.definition: A consolidated document describing outcomes of testing activities, including coverage, pass/fail, defects, and readiness indicators.
terms.description: Summarizes testing outcomes into decision-ready status for stakeholders and release gates.

terms.name: Release Readiness
terms.definition: A structured evaluation confirming the system meets required quality criteria to be released, considering results, defect status, performance, and completeness of testing.
terms.description: Defines the final go/no-go criteria based on evidence, coverage, and unresolved risk.

terms.name: Unit Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining scope, ownership, tooling, and criteria for validating isolated functions or modules.
terms.description: Defines how small code units are validated quickly and deterministically to prevent low-level regressions.

terms.name: Integration Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining validation of interactions between modules, services, databases, and external integrations.
terms.description: Defines how component boundaries are tested together to detect contract mismatches and integration failures.

terms.name: Smoke Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining minimal critical checks that confirm a build is deployable and the system is fundamentally operational.
terms.description: Defines fast, high-signal checks used after builds or deployments to quickly detect critical breakages.

terms.name: System Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining end-to-end validation of system behavior in an environment representative of production.
terms.description: Defines how end-to-end functionality is validated across UI, APIs, data, and integrations as a single system.

terms.name: Regression Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining how previously validated behavior is re-verified after changes to prevent regressions.
terms.description: Defines the repeatable regression suite and selection rules so changes do not reintroduce known defects.

terms.name: Security Testing Strategy
terms.definition: A testing strategy defining how security controls are validated, including authentication/authorization behavior, vulnerability checks, and secrets exposure prevention.
terms.description: Defines how security risks are tested and validated to reduce the chance of unauthorized access, data leakage, or insecure defaults.

terms.name: Performance and Load Testing
terms.definition: A testing approach validating system performance under expected and extreme loads, including latency, throughput, and resource behavior.
terms.description: Defines how load, stress, and soak tests are executed and how results are assessed against performance targets.

terms.name: Stability and Resilience Testing
terms.definition: A testing approach validating long-running stability and failure recovery behavior, including retries, timeouts, and degradation under faults.
terms.description: Defines how reliability is tested through long runs and fault scenarios to validate recovery and controlled failure behavior.

terms.name: AI Evaluation Strategy
terms.definition: A structured approach defining how AI outputs are evaluated using test sets, scoring methods, thresholds, and human review gates.
terms.description: Defines how AI behavior is judged for quality and safety without relying on exact text matching, enabling repeatable evaluation decisions.

terms.name: AI Test Scenarios
terms.definition: Structured evaluation scenarios for AI behavior including inputs, context, constraints, and expected characteristics validated by criteria and metrics.
terms.description: Defines representative prompts and contexts with expected properties such as correctness, completeness, grounding, and safe behavior.

terms.name: AI Regression Testing
terms.definition: A repeatable validation process ensuring changes to models, prompts, retrieval, or tools do not degrade previously validated AI behavior.
terms.description: Defines regression suites and comparison rules so AI quality does not drift when the system changes.

terms.name: Agent Execution Testing
terms.definition: A testing approach validating multi-step agent workflows including branching, retries, tool calls, failure handling, and final artifact correctness.
terms.description: Defines how agent runs are validated end-to-end so orchestration and tool use remain reliable and deterministic.

terms.name: Tool Invocation Validation
terms.definition: Validation ensuring tools are called with correct inputs, permissions, expected side effects, and compliant outputs under defined constraints.
terms.description: Defines how tool usage is verified to prevent unsafe actions, incorrect parameters, or inconsistent results.

terms.name: AI Observability Requirements
terms.definition: A set of required logging and monitoring signals for AI execution including prompt versions, model selection, retrieval traces, tool calls, latency, cost, errors, and safety events.
terms.description: Defines which AI signals must be captured so behavior can be audited, debugged, and monitored in production.

terms.name: AI Quality Metrics
terms.definition: Defined measurable indicators used to evaluate AI behavior quality such as task success rate, groundedness rate, refusal rate, and error rate.
terms.description: Defines how AI quality is quantified for evaluation, regression detection, and operational monitoring over time.
